case_name: Debidutt Bhagwati Prasad v. Harnandrai Badridas

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1323 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1323 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from judgment and order dated April 29, 1966 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal No. 109 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from. the judgment and order dated April 29, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal No. 109 of 1965.

facts.text: Debidutt Bhagwati Prasad obtained a money decree against Harnandrai Badridas in May 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In May 1956 one Debidutt Bhagwati.Prasad obtained a money decree against Harnandrai Badridas.

facts.text: Mr. S. Tibrewal appointed Receiver in insolvency proceeding against Durga Prasad Goinka in January 1959 for premises No. 99 and 128 Cotton Street, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1959 Mr. S. Tibrewal, a member of the Calcutta Bar was appointed Receiver in an insolvency proceeding against one Durga Prasad Goinka, a partner of the defendant firm in respect of premises No. 99 and 128 Cotton Street, Calcutta

facts.text: Mr. Tibrewal appointed receiver in execution of the decree obtained by Debidutt Bhagwati Prasad on 3 April 1958 for sale of the two premises.

anchor.surface_text: for the purpose of selling those properties. On 3 April 1958 Mr. Tibrewal was also appointed receiver in execution of the decree obtained by Debidutt Bhagwati Prasad for the sale of the two premises.

facts.text: Properties put up to sale by auction on 26 April 1958, Kanta Prosad Chotaria declared purchaser of premises No. 128 Cotton Street for Rs. 52,000/- and made deposit of Rs. 13,000/- as earnest money.

anchor.surface_text: On 26 April 1958 the properties were put up to sale by auction and one Kanta Prosad Chotaria was declared the purchaser of premises No. 128, Cotton Street for Rs. 52,000/-. Kanta Prosad made a deposit of Rs. 13,000. - as earnest money.

facts.text: On 19 May 1964, order directing receiver to complete sale within one month and Kanta Prosad to pay balance purchase money within that time.

anchor.surface_text: various proceedings after this at the end of which, on 19 May 1964, there was an order directing the receiver to companyplete the sale within one month from that date and Kanta Prosad was directed to pay the balance of the purchase money within that time.

facts.text: Receiver directed to execute and register conveyance on behalf of judgment-debtors if they refused.

anchor.surface_text: The receiver was directed to execute and register a companyveyance on behalf of the judgment-debtors who were the owners of premises No. 128, Cotton Street in case they refused to register the same.

facts.text: Purchaser directed to pay interest on balance from 13 June 1963 to 19 March 1964 or order to execute conveyance.

anchor.surface_text: The purchaser was by the same order directed to pay interest on the balance of the purchase money from 13 June 1963 to 19 March 1964 in default whereof there was an order number to execute the companyveyance.

facts.text: Receiver executed the conveyance on behalf of the judgment-debtor and the insolvent on 17 June 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On 17 June 1964 the receiver executed the companyveyance on behalf of the judgment-debtor and the insolvent.

facts.text: Purchaser requested receiver to make over possession on 19 June 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On 19 June 1964 the purchaser through his attorney requested the receiver to make over possession of premises No. 128, Cotton Street.

facts.text: Receiver further requested by attorney on 23 July 1964 to make over possession by letters to tenants and vacant possession of judgment-debtor's portion.

anchor.surface_text: On 23 July 1964 the receiver was further requested by the attorney to make over possession of the premises by the issue of letters of attorney addressed to each tenant in respect of portions which were tenanted and to make over vacant possession of that portion of the premises which was in the occupation of the judgment-debtor to the purchaser.

facts.text: Application made on 17 November 1964 for order on judgment-debtor to deliver vacant possession to receiver and receiver to deliver to purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: On 17th November 1964 an application was made praying inter alia for an order upon the judgment-debtor to deliver vacant possession of the premises in their occupation to the receiver and also a direction to the receiver to deliver vacant possession of the same to the purchaser.

facts.text: Executing court made order directing delivery of vacant possession.

anchor.surface_text: In due companyrse, the companyrt made an order in terms of that prayer

facts.text: On appeal, appellate court confirmed the original order.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal against that order in the appellate companyrt the original order was companyfirmed.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate from a judgment of the Calcutta High Court

facts.text: Appellant contends that after receiver executes conveyance, decree is satisfied and execution proceedings end, possession requires separate suit.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytention of the appellant before the appellate companyrt as well as before, us is that as soon as a receiver in execution has executed a companyveyance m favour of an auction purchaser the decree stands sates fled and there is an end of the execution proceedings so that the question of the auction-purchaser getting possession of the property is. a matter which has numberhing to do with the execution, discharge or satisfaction of the decree.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court followed full bench decision in Kailash Chandra Tarafdar v. Gopal Chandra Poddar.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Calcutta High Court has followed,- as indeed they were bound to follow, the full bench decision in Kailash Chandra Tarafdars case 1 .

facts.text: G. K. Mitter J. delivered judgment of appellate court.

anchor.surface_text: G. K. Mitter J. who delivered the judgment of the appellate companyrt

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with Calcutta High Court full bench in Kailash Chandra Tarafdar case.

anchor.surface_text: we find ourselves in agreement with the opinion of the full bench of the Calcutta High Court in Kailash Tarafdars case 3 .

issues.text: whether after an auction sale in execution of a decree a decree-holder auction-purchaser can move the executing court for delivery of vacant possession of an immovable property or whether he has to file a separate suit to get that possession

arguments.claim: as soon as a receiver in execution has executed a conveyance in favour of an auction purchaser the decree stands satisfied and there is an end of the execution proceedings so that the question of the auction-purchaser getting possession of the property is a matter which has nothing to do with the execution, discharge or satisfaction of the decree. Such a question does not fall to be determined by the executing court but can be decided only in a separate suit

arguments.claim: sec 47 does not apply to an order passed on an application under O.XXI r.95 by an auction-purchaser who was also the decree-holder; no distinction between decree-holder purchaser and stranger purchaser; after amount realised decree satisfied, possession unrelated

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Singh Gopal Singh Anr. v. Abdullah Habibullah 2  the Lahore High Court came to an entirely contrary decision. According to the Lahore High Court, sec. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure does not apply to an order passed on an application under O.XXI r. 95 by an auction-purchaser who was also the decree-holder.

arguments.claim: Supreme Court agrees with full bench of Calcutta High Court in Kailash Tarafdar case

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully gone through the various decisions cited before us and we find ourselves in agreement with the opinion of the full bench of the Calcutta High Court in Kailash Tarafdars case 3 .

arguments.claim: If confirmation of sale terminates all execution questions, difficult to see why legislature framed rules 95 to 102 under O XXI; proceedings for possession included in execution rules

anchor.surface_text: If a confirmation of the sale would finally terminate all questions as to execution of the decree it is difficult to appreciate why the legislature would frame such rules as rules 95 to 102 under o. XXI of the Code of Civil Procedure. We are in respectful agreement

arguments.claim: Sec. 47 should be construed liberally as per Privy Council in 1892 on sec 244 CPC 1882 and reiterated in Ganapathy v Krishnamachariar

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 47 in our view should be construed liberally. As far back as in 1892  4 , the Privy Council spoke strongly in favour of putting a  1  19 I.A. 160. T.L.R. 26 Lah. 252. I.L.R. 53 Cal. 781.  4  19 I.A 166. liberal construction on sec. 244 of the Code of. Civil Procedure.

arguments.claim: decree-holder who purchases at execution sale retains character as party to suit until delivery of possession

anchor.surface_text: If a liberal construction be put upon sec. 47 it is difficult to understand why a decree-holder who has been a party to the decree will shed his character as such party merely upon purchasing the property at the execution sale. After all, a decree-holder purchases the property in execution of his decree with the permission of the court.

arguments.claim: question raised by judgment debtor at time of delivery of possession concerning rights purchased or resistance relates to execution, discharge and satisfaction of decree between parties to suit

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to this consideration, if any question is raised by the judgment debtor at the time of delivery of possession concerning the nature of the rights purchased and if the judgment debtor offers any resistance to delivery of possession the question must be one which in our view relates to the execution, discharge and satisfaction of the decree and arises between the parties to the suit.

holdings.text: we find ourselves in agreement with the opinion of the full bench of the Calcutta High Court in Kailash Tarafdars case

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully gone through the various decisions cited before us and we find ourselves in agreement with the opinion of the full bench of the Calcutta High Court in Kailash Tarafdars case 3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: After reviewing conflicting High Court decisions including Lahore and Calcutta streams, Supreme Court prefers and adopts Calcutta full bench view resolving the core question

holdings.text: If a confirmation of the sale would finally terminate all questions as to execution of the decree it is difficult to appreciate why the legislature would frame such rules as rules 95 to 102 under o. XXI of the Code of Civil Procedure

anchor.surface_text: If a confirmation of the sale would finally terminate all questions as to execution of the decree it is difficult to appreciate why the legislature would frame such rules as rules 95 to 102 under o. XXI of the Code of Civil Procedure. We are in respectful agreement

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of Order XXI rules 95-102 demonstrates legislative intent to include possession proceedings as integral to execution post-sale confirmation

holdings.text: Sec. 47 in our view should be construed liberally

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 47 in our view should be construed liberally. As far back as in 1892 , the Privy Council spoke strongly in favour of putting a liberal construction on sec. 244 of the Code of Civil Procedure. of 1882

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on Privy Council precedents from 1892 and Ganapathy v Krishnamachariar endorsing liberal construction of predecessor Sec 244 CPC 1882 corresponding to Sec 47 CPC

holdings.text: There is no reason why he should not retain his character of a party to the suit until the delivery of possession to him of the property purchased by him

anchor.surface_text: If a liberal construction be put upon sec. 47 it is difficult to understand why a decree-holder who has been a party to the decree will shed his character as such party merely upon purchasing the property at the execution sale. After all, a decree-holder purchases the property in execution of his decree with the permission of the court. There is no reason why he should not retain his character of a party to the suit until the delivery of possession to him of the property purchased by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under liberal construction of Sec 47, decree-holder purchaser does not lose party status post-auction as purchase is with court permission in execution of decree

holdings.text: the question must be one which in our view relates to the execution, discharge and satisfaction of the decree and arises between the parties to the suit

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to this consideration, if any question is raised by the judgment debtor at the time of delivery of possession concerning the nature of the rights purchased and if the judgment debtor offers any resistance to delivery of possession the question must be one which in our view relates to the execution, discharge and satisfaction of the decree and arises between the parties to the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Given party status retention and liberal Sec 47 construction, disputes on possession rights or resistance by judgment-debtor fall within Sec 47 as between parties relating to execution/satisfaction

edges.explanation: Section 47 CPC directly grounds holding that relevant questions arise between parties relating to execution etc.

anchor.surface_text: If a liberal construction be put upon sec. 47 it is difficult to understand why a decree-holder who has been a party to the decree will shed his character as such party merely upon purchasing the property at the execution sale. After all, a decree-holder purchases the property in execution of his decree with the permission of the court. There is no reason why he should not retain his character of a party to the suit until the delivery of possession to him of the property purchased by him.
